unnormalised: Okay, so, you're planning a trip, eh? Awesome! But before you pack your bags and dream of chai in the hills or beaches in Goa, lemme tell you, there’s some serious number juggling involved. Not just the cost, but the IDs! It’s not as simple as just showing up with your charming smile.
normalised: Okay, so, you're planning a trip, eh? Awesome! But before you pack your bags and dream of chai in the hills or beaches in Goa, let me tell you, there’s some serious number juggling involved. Not just the cost, but the I-D-s! It’s not as simple as just showing up with your charming smile.

unnormalised: First things first, your flight. That e-ticket PNR number, like, say, 6XYZ89, keep it handy. Screenshot it, write it on your hand if you must (kidding… mostly!). You'll need it for EVERYTHING – checking in, boarding, asking for extra peanuts (okay, maybe not the peanuts). Airlines these days, they're all about that PNR life.
normalised: First things first, your flight. That e-ticket P-N-R number, like, say, six X-Y-Z eight nine, keep it handy. Screenshot it, write it on your hand if you must (kidding… mostly!). You'll need it for everything – checking in, boarding, asking for extra peanuts (okay, maybe not the peanuts). Airlines these days, they're all about that P-N-R life.

unnormalised: Then there's the Aadhaar card. Number like 1234-5678-9012, memorise it if you haven't already. It’s your go-to ID. It’s asked everywhere, from hotels to sim card purchases. Just be aware of the privacy stuff, okay? Maybe carry a physical copy just in case the phone dies.
normalised: Then there's the Aadhaar card. Number like one thousand two hundred and thirty four dash five thousand six hundred and seventy eight dash nine thousand and twelve, memorise it if you haven't already. It’s your go-to I-D. It’s asked everywhere, from hotels to sim card purchases. Just be aware of the privacy stuff, okay? Maybe carry a physical copy just in case the phone dies.

unnormalised: Passport, of course! If you're flying internationally. That little booklet holds magic. But make sure it’s valid. Expired passport = no vacation. The passport number, like ABC1234567, is crucial. Also, check the expiry date (dd/mm/yyyy format, usually). Been there, almost didn't get to Bangkok because I spaced out on the expiry date thing. Don’t be like me.
normalised: Passport, of course! If you're flying internationally. That little booklet holds magic. But make sure it’s valid. Expired passport equals no vacation. The passport number, like A-B-C one two three four five six seven, is crucial. Also, check the expiry date (D-D slash M-M slash Y-Y-Y-Y format, usually). Been there, almost didn't get to Bangkok because I spaced out on the expiry date thing. Don’t be like me.

unnormalised: Train travel? IRCTC registration is a must. Your user ID matters. Your PNR number, say something like 4567891230 – treat it like gold dust. Print your ticket; even though digital is cool, some TTs prefer the paper version still, for whatever reason.
normalised: Train travel? I-R-C-T-C registration is a must. Your user I-D matters. Your P-N-R number, say something like four billion five hundred and sixty seven million eight hundred and ninety one thousand two hundred and thirty – treat it like gold dust. Print your ticket; even though digital is cool, some T-T-s prefer the paper version still, for whatever reason.

unnormalised: And for road trips, well, there's the driver's license. Check that DL number, say UP7020100001234, is valid and you aren't breaking any rules. Plus, if you are going on a tour with a guide, it is important to check their Tourist Guide License number. It’s usually some format like GT2024/001.
normalised: And for road trips, well, there's the driver's license. Check that D-L number, say U-P seven zero two zero one zero zero zero zero one two three four, is valid and you aren't breaking any rules. Plus, if you are going on a tour with a guide, it is important to check their Tourist Guide License number. It’s usually some format like G-T two thousand and twenty four slash zero zero one.

unnormalised: Hotels love IDs. They'll want your Aadhaar, passport, DL – anything with a photo and your name on it. Keep copies handy. It makes check-in smoother. Sometimes they may also ask for a PAN number as well - like ABCDE1234F - especially if you are paying a big amount.
normalised: Hotels love I-D-s. They'll want your Aadhaar, passport, D-L – anything with a photo and your name on it. Keep copies handy. It makes check-in smoother. Sometimes they may also ask for a P-A-N number as well - like A-B-C-D-E one two three four F - especially if you are paying a big amount.

unnormalised: Basically, travel these days is like a number game. Keep your IDs organized, keep the numbers handy, and you'll be sipping on that coconut water on the beach faster than you can say "Incredible India!" Safe travels, folks! Don’t forget your charger!
